author: pcgeek86
body:
Overview
------------------

I'm not sure if this is a bug or expected behavior, but I'm fairly certain I'm doing this right. Basically I'm trying to suppress any output from appearing in the PowerShell host. To do this, I'm attempting to redirect the StdErr stream to the PowerShell Output stream, and then assigning the consolidated result to `$null`.

I can't seem to figure out how to prevent a native UNIX command from printing StdErr to the host.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

```
$TempPath = '{0}/pythontemptrevor' -f $HOME
mkdir $TempPath
$null = pip install --target $TempPath pip
$null = pip install --target $TempPath pip 2>1
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

No output is printed to stderr.

Actual behavior
---------------

* Output is printed to stderr (I think).
* A file named `1` is created.

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
PSEdition                      Core
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.18
CLRVersion
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

Cheers,
Trevor Sullivan

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
Right format is "2>&1".
Great article from June Blender  (@juneb Thanks!)https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/heyscriptingguy/2014/03/30/understanding-streams-redirection-and-write-host-in-powershell/

Also you can create a runspace without host and use it streams.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
`2>1` means redirect stderr to a file called `1`.  `2>&1` means redirect stderr to stdout.

Edit: looks like Ilya beat me to it :)

comments.author: pcgeek86
comments.body: I knew I was doing something wrong. :) Thanks!
